misconceptions.name: Solved the wrong problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even integers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a physics average-acceleration calculation using v0, v1, and t instead of computing the sum of even numbers among 5 integers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t, computes (v1 - v0) / t as an average acceleration, and print it as the result for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, test each for evenness, accumulate the sum of only the even ones, and print that sum. It should not compute or print anything about acceleration.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Program reads 3 numeric values instead of 5 integers
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints 'The average acceleration is ...'
Nowhere does the code check for even numbers or sum user-entered values
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or copied a solution for a different assignment (average acceleration) and did not adapt it to the current specification about summing even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words before coding. Then design the variables and calculations specifically for: (1) reading 5 integers, (2) checking if each is even, and (3) summing only the even ones.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every key part of the code (variable names, formula, output text) matches an average acceleration task and none matches the required 'sum of even numbers' behavior.

evidence.note: Code clearly implements an average-acceleration calculation and output, not a sum of even numbers among 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding how to sum user-entered numbers in a loop
misconceptions.description: The student uses a for-loop that adds the loop index (1 to 4) to a sum variable and comments that this is how they would sum 5 numbers, instead of reading and adding user inputs inside the loop.
misconceptions.student_belief: To sum 5 numbers, I can write a for-loop like 'for (int i = 1; i < 5; i++) sum += i;'. The loop counter itself represents the numbers being summed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum 5 numbers entered by the user, the loop should run 5 times, and in each iteration read a number from input (e.g., using nextInt()) and add that input value to the accumulator, not the loop index. Also, the bounds should ensure exactly 5 iterations.
symptoms: Loop runs from i = 1 to i < 5, which performs only 4 iterations
sum is updated with 'sum += i' rather than with a value read from the user
No input statement appears inside the loop
Comment explicitly suggests this is how they think to sum 5 numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between the loop counter and the data being processed. The student is thinking of 'i' as the numbers to be summed, rather than as a position/index used to control how many times input is read and processed.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the loop so that inside each iteration you (1) prompt/read the next integer from the user, and (2) add that read value to sum if it meets the condition (e.g., is even). The loop counter should usually just control how many times you repeat these steps, not be the data itself.
related_concepts: Separating control variables from data values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The comment directly states that this is how they think to sum 5 numbers, and the loop clearly adds the index instead of any user input.

evidence.note: Loop does not read input and sums the loop index from 1 to 4 instead; comment indicates this is the student's mental model for summing 5 numbers.

misconceptions.name: Reading the wrong quantity and kind of input values
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers as specified, the student reads 3 numeric values (v0, v1, t) and uses no mechanism to obtain 5 separate numbers from the user for processing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The program only needs to read three numbers from the user (v0, v1, and t) for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly 5 separate integer inputs from the user. Typically, this means either calling nextInt() five times or using a loop that calls nextInt() once per iteration until 5 integers have been read.
symptoms: Only three calls to input.nextDouble() appear in the program
The prompt text asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
No code structure (such as a loop) to collect 5 distinct values
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely transferred input handling code from a different problem without adjusting it to match the new requirement of reading five integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input logic to read 5 integers. Use either five explicit nextInt() calls or a loop that runs 5 times, reading one integer each iteration.
related_concepts: Designing input based on problem specification
Using loops to read multiple inputs
Distinguishing between single-value and multi-value input requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Both the prompt text and the exact number of input reads (three) conflict directly with the specification to read 5 integers.

evidence.note: Only three inputs are read and the prompt references v0, v1, and t, not five integers.

misconceptions.name: Using double instead of int for integer-based problem
misconceptions.description: The student uses double variables and nextDouble() for inputs where the problem explicitly asks for integers, which can obscure the intended integer/even logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable or equivalent to use double for these numeric inputs even though the problem describes them as integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifies integers, int should normally be used, and input should be read with nextInt(). This keeps types consistent and avoids mixing integer concepts (like even/odd) with floating-point values.
symptoms: All input variables (v0, v1, t) are declared as double
The code uses input.nextDouble() instead of input.nextInt()
No int variables are used even though the task is about integers and even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between general numeric types and integers, likely from reusing a floating-point physics example where double is appropriate.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use int and nextInt() when the specification calls for integers, especially when working with integer-specific concepts like even/odd. Reserve double for values that can be fractional.
related_concepts: Using the Scanner API (nextInt vs nextDouble)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The mismatch between the integer-based problem and the double-based implementation suggests a misunderstanding, though it may also stem from copy-paste rather than a deep misconception.

evidence.note: All inputs are read as double despite the assignment being stated in terms of integers and even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misuse of Loop Structure for Fixed Calculation
misconceptions.description: The student included a loop structure, but instead of using it to repeatedly read and process 5 user inputs, it is used to perform a fixed calculation (`1 + 2 + 3 + 4`). This demonstrates a misunderstanding of how control flow structures, like loops, are used to process dynamic data/input in typical programming tasks.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that a fixed loop (`for (int i = 1; i < 5; i++)`) is a general way to handle the quantity '5' needed for the problem, regardless of how the input is handled.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A loop must be used to iterate 5 times, and the input reading and conditional checking must occur inside the loop body to process the 5 distinct, dynamic inputs provided by the user.
symptoms: The loop runs for only i = 1, 2, 3, 4.
The variable 'i' (the loop index) is added to the sum, not a user input variable.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusing the loop counter (`i`) with the data that needs to be summed, and a general procedural misunderstanding of sequential input processing.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Your loop should iterate 5 times (i=0 to i<5). Inside the loop, you need to read the next number from the user, then check if that number is even.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The student's internal TODO ('I think this is how I'd sum 5 numbers if I needed to') directly points to this procedural misapplication of the loop.

evidence.note: This loop calculates 1+2+3+4=10. It does not read input or perform conditional summing based on even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Loop Counter as Data Source Instead of User Input
misconceptions.description: Student uses loop counter variable (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) as the values to sum, rather than reading user input into variables within the loop. The sum accumulates hardcoded loop values instead of numbers provided by the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that to sum numbers in a loop, you can use the loop counter itself as the values to add (sum += i), not realizing that data must come from an external source like user input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In a loop that processes user input, you must read each user value into a variable (e.g., int num = input.nextInt()) in each iteration, then operate on that value. The loop counter controls iteration count, not the data being processed.
symptoms: Loop computes sum of 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 = 10 (hardcoded integers)
No input.nextInt() or similar call inside the loop
Sum variable is independent of the user input that was read earlier
Values being summed are not from the user

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside the loop, add a line like 'int num = input.nextInt();' to read one user value per iteration. Then check if num is even before adding to sum. The loop counter i should control how many times you iterate, not provide the data.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The loop clearly uses i as the accumulation source (sum += i) with no input.nextInt() call. The student's comment 'I think this is how I\'d sum 5 numbers if I needed to' shows they attempted summing but disconnected from input reading.

misconceptions.name: Missing Even/Odd Filter Logic
misconceptions.description: The code contains no conditional statement to check if numbers are even (using n % 2 == 0 or equivalent). There is no filtering logic at all; the sum simply adds whatever values are present without testing divisibility by 2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that the task is simply to sum numbers in a loop, without recognizing that the phrase 'sum of even numbers' requires filtering to select only even values before adding them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The phrase 'sum of even numbers' means you must check each number to see if it is divisible by 2 (i.e., n % 2 == 0) and only add those numbers to the sum. Numbers that are odd should be skipped.
symptoms: No if statement checking divisibility
No n % 2 == 0 comparison
No filtering or conditional logic in accumulation
All values would be summed equally (if the input issue were fixed)
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete problem analysis or failure to recognize that 'even numbers' requires a filter. Student may have focused only on the looping/summing aspect and missed the key filtering requirement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an if statement inside the loop: if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; } This checks if num is even before adding it to the sum. The modulo operator % returns the remainder after division; if the remainder is 0, the number is even.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code completely lacks any conditional or filtering logic. The requirement for checking even numbers is explicit in the problem statement ('sum of even numbers') and the sample shows 14 (8+2+4) not 22 (3+8+2+7+4).

evidence.note: Loop body has no conditional check for even numbers. No if statement testing n % 2 == 0.

evidence.snippet: // TODO: maybe I need some loop? but assignment just needs one calculation
evidence.note: Comment suggests student did not fully analyze the problem requirements, focusing only on loop structure rather than the filtering requirement

misconceptions.name: Incorrect idea of how to sum multiple numbers using a loop
misconceptions.description: The student sketches a loop to "sum 5 numbers" by adding the loop index i (1 to 4) to sum, instead of adding user-provided values. This suggests confusion between the role of a loop counter and the data being processed.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I needed to sum 5 numbers, I could write a for-loop like 'for (int i = 1; i < 5; i++) { sum += i; }', using the loop variable itself as the values to add.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A loop counter is typically used to control how many times the loop runs or to index into data; the values you want to sum should be the actual numbers (e.g., read from input inside the loop) or elements of an array, not the counter itself. For this task, the loop should read an int each iteration, check if it is even, and then add that input value (not i) to the sum.
symptoms: Loop adds the loop index i to sum rather than any input values.
Loop bounds (i = 1; i < 5) only run 4 times, which does not align with '5 numbers'.
No input operations appear inside the loop, so user-provided numbers are not being processed there.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between the loop control variable and the data that needs to be processed and accumulated, and lack of practice placing input and condition checks inside the loop body.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the loop so that each iteration: (1) reads the next integer from the user, (2) checks if it is even (n % 2 == 0), and (3) if even, adds that input value to sum. The loop counter should only control how many times this happens.
related_concepts: Distinguishing loop indices from data values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The comment explicitly states this is how they think they would sum 5 numbers, and the loop body currently sums the index i rather than any input; however, the code is partially a sketch, so there is some uncertainty about their final intent.

evidence.note: Student comment and loop show they plan to sum the loop index (1..4) rather than values read from input, indicating a misunderstanding of how to sum multiple user-provided numbers.

misconceptions.name: Loop control variable confused with input data
misconceptions.description: The student uses a for loop with sum += i; but appears to believe this reads and sums input values. In reality, this sums only the hardcoded loop variable values (1+2+3+4=10) and never reads any user input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that for (int i = 1; i < 5; i++) sum += i; will read and sum 5 numbers from user input. The TODO comment suggests this: I think this is how I'd sum 5 numbers if I needed to
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To read and process multiple input values in a loop, you must call an input method (e.g., input.nextInt()) inside the loop body and store the result in a variable. The loop variable i is only for counting iterations, not for holding input data. Example: for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); if (num % 2 == 0) sum += num; }
symptoms: Sum is always 1+2+3+4=10, regardless of input values
User inputs are never actually read by the loop
No input values are checked for evenness
misconceptions.root_cause: Common novice misconception: confusion between loop iteration variable and input data. The student likely encountered loop syntax but doesn't fully understand that reading input requires explicit input method calls.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside your for loop, use int num = input.nextInt(); to read each integer. Then check if (num % 2 == 0) and add it to the sum. Remember: loop variable i counts iterations; a separate variable stores the actual input value.
related_concepts: Storing and retrieving data from variables
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence. The TODO comment explicitly indicates this misconception, the loop code itself demonstrates adding the loop variable not input, and no input statements appear inside the loop.

evidence.note: Loop adds loop variable i (producing 1+2+3+4=10), not any user input. No input.nextInt() or similar call inside loop.

All numbers (even and odd) are treated the same
